title: Can you get banned if you didnt do anything wrong but people still reported you
body:
so i was playing a blind pick after doing some work in my garage. and it was chill i was having fun. and then i get ganked by their whole team and instantly die, so i say "hello can you guys call mia pls" and then this one guy is like "we did, dont try us, we are a group of four and will get you banned" and the rest of the game they proceeded to say stuff in /all chat like "omg no way yasuo just called me a f**king n**ger" and other completely untrue stuff. and telling them to report me. and i know for sure they all reported me for being "toxic" even tho the only thing i might have said is "fuck" when i died and almost killed someone but idk if thats chat restrictionable. 
and also they spam pinged me the whole game to the point i had to take off my headphones because it was driving me mad.
Which brings me to my other point being, Why is it not an option to completely mute pings, like i know some people /mute all in the beginning of games which i might start doing because its cancer, and people would /mute all pings if it was an option and riot might not like to just cut off all communication. but shouldnt it be my choice if i want to cut out communication, at the very least there should be a better system that limits how much pings you can ping, like if you ping 100 times in 10 minutes thats obviously a problem. 

But is it possible for me to get something stupid like chat restriction or even a ban because these children wanted to be upset.

*UPDATE* I didn't get banned or even chat restriction, YET..
Thanks for all the helpful comments :)

> Actually, Erdrik is correct here.

> You cannot ever be punished for saying nothing .. unless of course it's for something gameplay related like feeding, afking or cheating. But, you can never be punished for offensive language, hate speech or verbal abuse if you said nothing.

Say I'm toxic in Games 1-4. But in game 5, I behave and am given a bogus report anyway that triggers the punishment. I would still be punished due to behaviors in Games 1-4, so the bogus report would be technically counted.

This is correct and is exactly what I'm saying.

If someone has a history of toxicity, even if the report that triggered the punishment was false, that will trigger an investigation and get you banned due to your history.

What should happen is - If a bogus report triggers my punishment, that report and the punishment should be thrown out completely.

Basically, if I'm feeling spiteful, I can false report you, gambling that you said something in a previous game. Even if my report will be thrown out, past behaviors will be used as evidence to justify your ban.

The other thing is we don't know how far back Riot goes through your history to justify bans. Is it x  games? Is it x months? The further you go back, the more likely you will be to find something.

It wasn't the report that triggered the punishment, what triggered the punishment was your own toxic behavior in the previous games. The false report merely triggered the discovery of the behavior. 

The notion that if a false report leads to the detection of genuine bad behavior, then they should turn a blind eye to it is nonsensical. Imagine if somebody tells you your wife is cheating on you with the neighbor, you investigate it and find out that she isn't doing anything with the neighbor but with her coworker instead. Would you just overlook it because the original accusation was false?

>It wasn't the report that triggered the punishment, what triggered the punishment was your own toxic behavior in the previous games. The false report merely triggered the discovery of the behavior. 

The problem is 95% of lol players could be banned under the current standards when calling someone a retard is all it takes. Any swear words are offensive language. Any arguments are negative or verbal. Leaving is an AFK, doing poorly could be considered an int feed, begging the team to surrender is negative. Asking for reports is negative. Any complaints are negative. Any insults are verbal. Not grouping probably has a category. The jury is out on picking off meta/off role with the Support Nunu situation since they banned then unbanned him, amongst other issues.

>The notion that if a false report leads to the detection of genuine bad behavior, then they should turn a blind eye to it is nonsensical. Imagine if somebody tells you your wife is cheating on you with the neighbor, you investigate it and find out that she isn't doing anything with the neighbor but with her coworker instead. Would you just overlook it because the original accusation was false?

It's really not what is going on here.

If you are throwing out bogus reports and it is the one that triggers the punishment, that report and the punishment should be thrown out. If you get reported the next game legitimately, then it's a fair ban.

Again though, that all depends on how far back Riot is going here, which is a big question that needs answered. How many games do Rioters look back on when justifying bans? Is there a set number of games or is it up to the staff member to decide? If there is no set amount of games, it would leave the door open for interpretation and that's never good.

We also have another issue with the various reporting categories. Verbal, negative and offensive language are all 3 different categories. Do all players know this and/or care? I'm doubtful of that. I'm personally a revenge reporter and if you get me mad, I'm going to pick 3 categories to report you in because I can. We also do know, when you get banned, it doesn't specify whether it was for negative or verbal, even though they are separate things. Mine says "extremely inflamatory and offensive", but yet I didn't use swear words or use offensive verbiage. That's no report category, so I would think the verbal and negative reports counted together even though they are separate things. That's not right.

There is a threshold. It's not just "was this guy ever toxic?" or most of the playerbase would probably be punished. For an ethical and correct system, that threshold has to be the same for everyone. If you introduce false evidence to tip someone over the edge, that is not moral or acceptable in any way. 

Likewise, if you're nearly past the legal alcohol limit while driving and I inject you with whiskey, it would not be moral if you got arrested for it. It doesn't matter that it's better if you drink nothing at all before driving. There are rules and they need to be applied uniformly. This is basic logic and moral reasoning. It's never OK for false evidence to count against you in any way. It doesn't matter what you did in the past. The triggering evidence has to be valid or it's all BS.

>Likewise, if you're nearly past the legal alcohol limit while driving and I inject you with whiskey, it would not be moral if you got arrested for it. It doesn't matter that it's better if you drink nothing at all before driving.

That's a completely invalid analogy. A better one would be, if there was a cop sitting on the side of the road with a speedgun, and he would stop and ask for a breathalyzer test if people went past above the speed limit.  If the gun turned out to be overestimating speeds, then yeah, you couldn't be punished for breaking the speed limit. But if the test proved you were DUIing, then of course you would get punished for **that**.

The false report didn't increase the severity of your actual infractions in any way, it just increased the likelyhood that they would be discovered.

If people report you frequently and incorrectly, all that will happen is that those reports with time become "correct" according to the system. If people don't like what you say, it means you have no right to say it according to the system. It doesn't matter if you're right or not. It's about how they feel.
